Title: The Warring States

reviewText: THE WARRING STATES is a curious film, at times capturing the `bigness' and `boldness' that only the best period pictures can muster. It feels rich, epic and lush - precisely the way a film embracing key moments in a nation history should be - and it loudly cries out to say something definitive about `The Warring States Period' of Chinese history ... but, for the life of me, I have absolutely no idea what that statement may have been because so much of the rest of STATES feels muddled, confused, and unfinished. At times, it's a war picture. At times, it's a picture about peace. At times, it's a romance. At times, it's a family drama. At times, it's a bit of a comedy, and, still at other times, it's quietly meditative. It's all over the map - figuratively and literally - and I'm not completely certain that anyone involved knew precisely what STATES wanted to be.STATES is essentially the story of would-be brothers, Sun Bin (played winningly by Sun Hong-Lei) and Pang Juan (underplayed by Francis Ng). Sun Bin is a descendant of Sun Tzu, the famous military strategist, and it's believed that Sun possesses the tactics to defeat any enemy on the field of battle. By a curious twist of fate, these two `adopted' brothers end up as military advisors for warring nations. Pang eventually captures and tortures Sun, hoping to uncover the secrets of military strategy; but, before Sun will confess, he's rescued by his people (the nation of Qi), and the two men are put on a dangerous collision course leading their respective armies in a battle whose outcome will shape centuries and civilization to come.Simply put, the delivered film feels horribly incomplete, almost as if there was another four or five or maybe even nine hours cut from it and sitting on the editing room floor, and the strength of the two leads isn't strong enough to rescue STATES from obscurity. Motivations are never perfectly clear - with the exception of Hong-Lei's Sun Bin, a military man who longs for peace - and quite a bit seems lost in the shuffle of events. Significant characters appear for what only ends up as minutes, if not seconds; meanwhile, other sequences appear in jumbled and confusing flashbacks inserted later in the picture so that what came early makes sense. Get it? You may not know how or why something happened as it unfolds chronologically within the story, so the director inserts a flashback to clarify it later. I've seen some mysteries pull this trick time and time again, but a serious history picture? I kid you not, but I ended the film and immediately began searching online to see if this motion picture had been edited from a longer working draft. (Movie buffs out there noted some similar results with RED CLIFF; the completed film was actually two pictures, but an `international cut' was released, trimming the total near-five-hour run time almost in half and sacrificing fairly large and relevant chunks of story.) I couldn't believe this story didn't exist in some longer version; but, as of this review, I've been unable to find any other release.Otherwise, production detail is impeccable. Costuming is very impressive. The musical score is particularly stirring. The cinematography and location shooting are excellent. Special effects, in my opinion, present a mixed bag, ranging from very polished to tragically amateurish; some of the shortcomings are clearly due to the scope of the film - much like in the final installment of THE LORD OF THE RINGS, massive armies face off against one another, so tremendous use of CGI has been employed here, to dazzlingly inconsistent effect. Again, I couldn't help wondering how much the scope of the film weighed down the production and post-production processes; there's clearly enough story here for multiple films - if not a massive, cinematic miniseries not unlike THE LORD OF THE RINGS - but, sadly, that was never delivered. Instead, it's an ever-fascinating near-miss that quite probably could have been a landmark achievement on the silver screen: we'll never know because it was never tried.Note to the Chinese: repeated fancy cut, swipe, or chop edits tend to have the negative effect of reminding the viewer that "you're watching a movie" and ultimately distract the viewer from being absorbed by the narrative. Instead of pulling the audience in, you end up pushing them back from any emotional connection to the characters and situations. STATES is full (and I mean F-U-L-L) of creative dissolves and crossfades and what'sits galore, so much so that I began wondering if the editor was new to the art form and wanted to experiment with every possible way to cut a film! Some sequences end up feeling a bit like visual gibberish while others go on (and on and on and on) too long hammering home the same point. It's a curious failure because it's so inconsistent throughout, and the surplus of edits again made me wonder precisely how much story had to be trimmed.STATES ends up being a five-star-effort in a two-and-one-half star package, at best. That's sad because I think the Chinese deserved better. I recommend it for viewing only for fans of international cinema and/or film students because I think it's definitely deserving of a single pass. Casual film fans may find the picture a bit more confusing than need be but may find it worthwhile. It's an impressive film that I desperately wanted to like much more than I did.In the interests of fairness, I'm happy to disclose that New Video provided me with a DVD screener for the purpose of completing this review.
summary: THE WARRING STATES End Up At War with Itself
Title: The Warring States

reviewText: its about the friendship between two general from the opposite, and a women they both fall in love with, its very touching
Title: The Warring States

reviewText: I was super excited to check out the Chinese epic "The Warring States" as it tells an incredible and fascinating historical tale. I love this genre of film and there have been some truly masterful examples to come from Chinese filmmakers. However, despite having a rich and complicated tale to tell, director Jin Chen seems unsure of just what movie he wanted to make. After a terrifically staged opening battle sequence, I settled in for a dynamic and dramatic movie--but the tone of "The Warring States" shifts all over the place and undermines the power inherent in this true life legend. There are elements of slapstick comedy, special effects laden adventure, political intrigue drama, frothy romance, and tragedy interwoven into the film's screenplay. And quite frankly, some of these many factions seem at war with one another. I never could take this picture very seriously despite its sometimes harrowing subject matter, and that was a real disappointment. Instead of a sweeping and memorable epic, it ends up being a jumble of conflicting styles and ideas.The film chronicles the brotherhood and rivalry between two notable military strategists during China's Warring States Period. Through the course of the film, you know that the two will eventually meet on the battlefield as betrayal and political machinations divide the land. The film's lead is Sun Hong-Lei (portraying Sun Bin) who is painted throughout the film's first half as a wise buffoon. This was perhaps the most disconcerting aspect of the film as it struggled for a strangely comic tone. Sun Bin meets an indestructible female general (literally she battles dozens of men on her own and emerges victorious every time) and the two forge a working relationship and an ill-conceived romance. I suppose we're supposed to see passion (which would certainly have heightened later scenes), but it felt more like an eccentric uncle and his entitled niece. Jing Tian is a likable actress, but it's hard to bring much realism to a role that is part battle-hardened veteran, part coquettish schoolgirl, and part super-charged videogame avatar. Nothing, in fact, rings true in this relationship or in either of these characters.The film gets progressively more serious and more interesting, however. Frances Ng adds a nice amount of gravitas as the other title character. But it's almost a case of too little, too late. All of a sudden we're supposed to shift our attention from lightweight comic antics to harrowing sequences of torture. And then the movie goes into full overblown tragedy mode. Nothing about the narrative momentum seemed to flow naturally. If the film hadn't started so loose and silly, perhaps the ending would have had a real impact--but it doesn't earn genuine emotional investment. SMALL VAGUE SPOILER: One character falls off a mountain in one sequence and STILL gets a showy death scene in the next. Huh? They fell at exactly the right moment onto the right spot without being killed by FALLING OFF A MOUNTAIN? Still, the film is filled with plenty of great visuals. I didn't actually hate "The Warring States," I just see it as a big missed opportunity. Grandiose historical epic or lightweight action comedy--one or the other please. About 2 1/2 stars from me, I'll round up because the actual story is terrific. KGHarris, 11/11.
summary: A Muddled Chinese Epic That Strains To Be A Comedy, An Action Picture, A Romance And A Tragedy
Title: The Warring States

reviewText: What I find so fascinating about this film, is not its length, but period of time in the past.  This was a very turbulent time with unceasing warfare for a long period of time.  This film takes this and weaves web of intrigues and love for a little over two(2) hours of fascinating entertainment.  LOVE CAN HAVE GAINS AND LOSSES.  NJMJr.
Title: The Warring States

reviewText: Wow this movie was amazing. The scenes were breathe taking the story line just touching to the heart. I am very happy I found it on netflix and now I'm going to own it. It's must see movie.
